ygData.messageBody:
Ah, thank you for the info. Is there a spot where we can write back to him, for if he reads where
we write I would gladly put my two cents into it.

As for answering your email *I know you didn't ask for one :)*, but for the general populations
*not just mine or yours but for everyone reading this*, I believe that if Sony wants us to sell to
other players to make a profit instead of vendors, they are limiting our game play, if they want
best of both worlds *Sony* in their ideology of how the game should be run, then they need to fix
it so that IF someone wants to sell to a PC they might get more depending on what they ask for, but
if they want to sell to a NPC they will get less. Now, the way they have it setup now, it's not
even worth maken the items to sell to PC's because what PC in their right mind would spend 2pp on a
pie tin ? This is the minimum amount that should be offered if sold to a PC, because of the drastic
increase in price for sketching of a Pie Tin. They must work on it more before implementing a
number throwen into the skill, so that it's just not profitable at all. Again, Sony is limiting us
in how we play the game, if someone chooses to sit on their butts and make PP all day, so be it, as
we all know, you can spend 300pp in about 5-10 minutes if you are buying weapons or armor of
considerable value, either case it's our choice.

P.S if anyone believes this should not be talked about here, please either delete it when you see
my name with this subject, or show me a spot where we can talk more about it....besides their
webboards :)

Thulgar
Grand Master of the Mystical Knights
http://www.efni.com/~thulgar

Aaron Braunstein wrote:

> I have read at least two interviews with Brad McQuaid
> describing how they view trade skills, and he has explicitly stated
> in no uncertain terms that they do not want any of the player trade
> skills to be implemented in such a way so as to allow for a player to
> purchase items from vendors, execute their skill, and sell the
> results of their efforts back to vendors at a profit. The way they
> want it to work is to offer players a 'sweet spot' between what they
> paid for materials and what NPC vendors charge for an equivilant item
> to what a player can make themselves through their tradecraft. This
> way, a player is encouraged to sell their wares at a profit to other
> players and not at a loss to vendors.
> In this way, they want to stimulate the "player run economy"
> and not a "kick back and make a bunch of plat just interacting with
> vendors"-type approach. I'm not saying I agree with it, I'm just
> passing on what I know to be true... not player speculation or rumor,
> but actual statements from The Man. :)
>
